questions.question: Question 1: The basal cardiac output in adults is around
questions.explanation: The basal cardiac output in adults is around 5.5 litres. Cardiac output is given by, Cardiac Output = Heart Rate ™ Stroke Volume. In a resting, supine man cardiac output averages about 5.0 L/min (70 mL × 72 beats/min).

questions.question: Question 2: The cardiac output can be determined by all except:
questions.explanation: V/Q ratio not used to determine cardiac output. Measurement of cardiac output: • Fick principle • Dye dilution/thermodilution • Doppler plus echocardiograph • MRI

questions.question: Question 3: Cardiac output in litre per minute divided by heart rate gives
questions.explanation:
Cardiac output in litre per minute divided by heart rate gives stroke volume. Cardiac output is given by, Cardiac Output = Heart Rate ™ Stroke Volume. The stroke volume is the amount of blood pumped out of each ventricle per beat, is about 70 mL 
from each ventricle in a resting man in the supine position.

questions.question: Question 4: Ejection fraction is
questions.explanation:
Ejection fraction is SV/EDV. The amount of blood ejected by each ventricle per stroke at rest is 70–‘0 mL. The end-diastolic 
ventricular volume is about 130 mL. The ejection fraction is the percentage of the end-diastolic 
ventricular volume that is ejected with each stroke, is about 65%.

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient with cardiac output 5L/min and body surface area 1.7m2. What will be the cardiac 
index (L/min/m2)?
questions.explanation:
Cardiac index is the cardiac output per minute per square meter of body surface. Cardiac Index = Cardiac output / body surface area. 506 
Sold by @itachibot Therefore Cardiac index = 5L/min /1.7m2= 2.‘4 L

questions.question: Question 6: Volume determining preload is
questions.explanation:
Volume determining preload is End diastolic volume. Preload is the initial stretch on muscle at the end of diastole. Preload is equal to End diastolic 
volume (EDV) and is determined by venous return to heart.

questions.question: Question 7: Starling's law implies:

options.a: Increased heart rate leads to increased cardiac output
options.b: Increased discharge leads to increased cardiac output
options.c: Increased venous return leads to increased cardiac output
options.d: Increased blood pressure leads to increased cardiac output

questions.explanation:
Starling's law implies increased venous return leads to increased cardiac output. Frank-Starling law: The energy of contraction is proportional to the initial length of the cardiac 
muscle fiber. The length of the muscle fibers is proportional to the end-diastolic volume, which is determined 
by venous return.

questions.question:
Question 8: Venous return to the heart during quiet standing is facilitated by all of the following factors 
except  
.

options.d: Increased arterial pressure due to gravitation.

questions.explanation:
Venous return to the heart during quiet standing is not facilitated by increased arterial pressure. Factors that facilitate venous return to the heart: • Calf muscles contract and pump blood through veins. • Valves don't allow the retrograde flow of blood through veins. • Deep fascia by forming a supporting structure to veins. 507 
Sold by @itachibot ’ote: The pulsations of artery helps in increasing lymph flow .

questions.question: Question 9: When a person changes position from standing to supine,

options.b: Venous return to heart rises immediately
options.d: Decrease in blood flow to the lung apices

questions.explanation:
When a person changes position from standing to supine, venous return to heart rises 
immediately. On standing, Gravitational pull causes venous pooling of blood in the legs. On 
supine position, this gravitational pull equalizes over body, causing the pooled blood to return 
back to heart. Other options: Option A: Heart rate decreases because of increased cardiac output and increased BP via 
baroreceptor reflex. Option C: Cerebral blood flow will remain constant due to autoregulation. Option D: Blood flow to the apex of lung will be high due to high cardiac output.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 30-year-old woman has a resting heart rate of 70-beats/min. Her pressure-volume diagram 
of the left ventricle is given below. What is her cardiac output (in mL/min)? (Point 2 
corresponds to 120 ml)
questions.explanation:
In this case, the patient has a heart rate of 70-beats/min and the stroke volume can be determined 
from the given pressure-volume diagram. Point 2 corresponds to the EDV(End diastolic volume) = 120 mL Point 1 corresponds to the ESV(End systolic volume) = 50 mL Thus, stroke volume (SV) = EDV – ESV = 120 – 50 = 70 mL Therefore, Cardiac output = HR ™ SV = 70 ™ 70 = 4‘00 mL/min. 508 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: 500 
Sold by @itachibot A sister donated one of her kidneys to her brother. What would be the effect on her cardiac 
output?
questions.explanation:
Surgical removal of kidney leads to decrease in cardiac output. Amputation of a limb or surgical removal of organs like kidney removes a parallel circuit 
thus increasing total peripheral vascular resistance. As the resistance increases, afterload 
increases hence decreasing stroke volume. CO= HR × SV, therefore decrease in stroke volume leads to decrease in cardiac output.

questions.explanation:
The duration of atrial diastole is 0.7 sec. Cardiac Cycle Even

questions.question: Question 13: The indication of the end of the isovolumetric relaxation phase is when

options.a: Ventricular pressure raise above atrial pressure
options.b: Ventricular pressure falls below atrial pressure
options.c: Ventricular pressure falls below aortic pressure
options.d: ventricular pressure rises above aortic pressure

questions.explanation:
The indication of the end of the isovolumetric relaxation phase is when ventricular pressure falls 
below atrial pressure. Events of the Cardiac Cycle Diastole • Protodiastole Before the semilunar valve closes, even though ventricular muscle is relaxed, blood flow into great 
vessels is due to momentum of blood. • Iso-volumetric Relaxation The ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, 
with all valves closed. • Ventricular Filling Isovolumetric relaxation ends when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and the 
AV valves open, permitting the ventricles to fill. • Atrial Systole During the last third of diastole, the atria contract and give additional thrust to the inflow of blood 
into the ventricles. It correlates with 'a' wave in JVP. Systole • Isovolumetric Contraction 509 
Sold by @itachibot The ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not 
change, with all valves closed. It correlates with the ‘c’ wave of JVP. • Ventricular Ejection When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the valves open, and 
ventricular ejection begins. Peak pressures in the left and right ventricles are about 120 and 25 
mmHg, respectively.

questions.question: Question 14: During the cardiac cycle, the opening of the aortic valve takes place at the
questions.explanation:
Opening of the aortic valve takes place at the end of the isovolumetric contraction. When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the semilunar valves 
(aortic and pulmonary valves) open, and ventricular ejection begins.

questions.question:
Question 15: 501 
Sold by @itachibot The effect of increased heart rate on cardiac cycle is that it 
.

options.a: Decrease the duration of systole and diastole.
options.b: Increase the duration of systole and diastole.
options.c: Decrease the duration of systole more than diastole.
options.d: Decrease the duration of diastole more than systole.

questions.explanation:
The effect of increased heart rate on cardiac cycle is that it decreases the duration of diastole more 
than systole. The duration of systole is much more fixed than that of diastole, so when the heart rate is 
increased, diastole is shortened to a much greater degree. Coronary blood flow and ventricular 
filling occur in diastole.

questions.question: Question 16: Electromechanical systole is the time interval between

options.c: R wave and first heart sound
options.d: Q wave and second heart sound

questions.explanation:
510 
Sold by @itachibot Electromechanical systole is the time interval between Q wave and second heart sound. To record this both ECG and phonocardiography are required.

questions.question: Question 17: The pressure-volume curve is shifted to the left in:
questions.explanation:
The pressure-volume curve is shifted to the left in Mitral stenosis. The PV loop is shifted to the right when there is volume overload (increased EDV). The PV loop is shifted to the left in case of increased contractility or decreased compliance 
(decreased EDV). Effect of Valvular Diseases on PV loop: • Mitral stenosis: Left and down. • Mitral regurgitation: Width increased and height decreased. • Aortic stenosis: Tall with steep slope. • Aortic regurgitation: Right and tall. 511 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 18: Dicrotic notch is caused by
questions.explanation:
Dicrotic notch is caused by closing of aortic valve. The dicrotic notch, a small oscillation in the falling phase of the pulse wave caused by vibrations 
set up when the aortic valve shuts. 512 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: First heart sound and second heart sound are respectively due to 502 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Opening of semilunar and atrioventricular valves
options.b: Closure of semilunar and atrioventricular valves
options.c: Closure of atrioventricular and semilunar valves
options.d: Opening of atrioventricular and semilunar valves

questions.explanation:
First heart sound and second heart sound are respectively due to closure of atrioventricular (AV) 
and semilunar valves.

questions.question: Question 20: The fourth heart sound is caused by:

options.a: Closure of aortic and pulmonary valves
options.b: Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole
options.d: Closure of mitral and tricuspid valves

questions.explanation:
The fourth heart sound is caused by ventricular filling. A fourth sound is heard immediately before the first sound when atrial pressure is high or the 
ventricle is stiff in conditions such as ventricular hypertrophy. It is due to ventricular filling and is 
rarely heard in normal adults. 513 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 21: “a” wave on JVP is for
questions.explanation: "a" wave in JVP represents atrial contraction. Waves of JVP : • a- atrial systole pushing the blood to the ventricles. • c- isovolumetric contraction of ventricles causing the tricuspid valve to bulge. • x'- fall in atrial pressure during ventricular systole due to pull of valve leaflets. • v- venous filling which creates an increase in atrial pressure. • y- passive filling of ventricles by a passive flow of the blood from the right atrium.

questions.question: Question 22: 'c' wave in JVP is seen in

options.b: Slow filling at end of diastole

questions.explanation:
'c' waves are produced by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during the 
Iso-volumetric contraction of the right ventricle. 514 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 23: The x descent in jugular venous pressure corresponds to  
 phase of the cardiac cycle.
questions.explanation:
The x descent in jugular venous pressure corresponds to the ventricular systole of the cardiac 
cycle. The jugular venous pulse • The waves in JVP reflect the pressure changes in the right atrium. • The internal jugular vein is preferred because the external jugular vein is valved and not directly 
in line with the superior vena cava and right atrium. • a wave: Corresponds to right atrial contraction. • c wave: Corresponds to the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during 
isovolumetric ventricular contraction. 515 
Sold by @itachibot • x descent: Corresponds to the atrial relaxation as the ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve 
during ejection. • v wave: Corresponds to the venous filling of the right atrium against a closed tricuspid valve. • y descent: Corresponds to fall in right atrial pressure during passive emptying of the right atrium 
into the right ventricle.

questions.question: Question 24: C wave of JVP represents:

options.a: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

questions.explanation:
'C' wave in JVP represents tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular 
contraction. Characteristics of JVP : • a wave corresponds to atrial systole which causes regurgitation of some blood into the great 
veins. • c wave occurs due to the increase in atrial pressure caused by bulging of the tricuspid valve into 
the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction. • x descent occurs due to the fall in atrial pressure during ventricular systole due to pulling of 
valve leaflets. • v wave is seen at the end of ventricular contraction and occurs due to the slow venous filling 
which causes an increase in atrial pressure. • y descent occurs due to the passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle.

questions.question: Question 25: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is:
questions.explanation:
Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is Bainbridge reflex. 516 
Sold by @itachibot Atrial Reflex Control of Heart Rate: The Bainbridge Reflex • The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals 
through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. • Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase 
heart rate and strength of heart contraction. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex: • Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. Juxta capillary 
region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) causes profound brady- 
cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. Cushing Reflex: • When ICP is increased, the blood supply to RVLM neurons is compromised. • The local hypoxia and hypercapnia causes an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing 
hypertension, bradycardia and irregular respiration. • The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

questions.question: Question 26: Arrange the following events in the sequence in which they occur, after 'p wave' in ECG:
questions.explanation:
The correct sequence of events that occur after the p-wave is 1-2-4-3, ie:- a wave in JVP  First heart sound  T wave in ECG  Rapid filling of ventricles. The sequence of the events in this question can be better understood with the following diagram: • The p wave in the ECG represents atrial depolarization, which causes contraction of the atria, 
represented by the 'a' wave in the JVP. Atrial contraction causes final filling of the ventricles 
(fourth phase of ventricular diastole) 517 
Sold by @itachibot • Atrial contraction is followed by the closure of the mitral valve, which causes the first-heart 
sound. • This is followed by the isovolumetric contraction of the ventricle, which causes c wave in JVP, 
due to bulging of the tricuspid valve. This is followed by the rapid ejection phase of the ventricle. • The T wave of ECG occurs during ventricular repolarization, which is followed by the opening of 
the mitral valve, followed by rapid filling phase of the ventricle (second phase of ventricular 
diastole). ’ote: Passive rapid filling occurs as the mitral valve opens just before atrial contraction occurs.

questions.explanation:
